cip.title: Critical Infrastructure Protection (CIP)
cip.text: Official standards created under order of the government and direction of NERC that give utilities guidance on how to protect the North American Electric Bulk Electric System from cyber-attack.

bes.title: Bulk Electric System (BES)
bes.text: The significant power plants, transmission lines, and associated equipment that make up North American's large interconnected electrical system. Excludes distribution systems.

nerc.title: North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC)
nerc.text: NERC is a non-profit formed by utilities to improve the reliability of the Bulk Electric System and secretly tasked by the government to prepare the industry for the coming metallic onslaught.

high.title: High Impact
high.text: High Impact facilities are large Control Centers and Backup Control Centers. This includes data centers that house cyber assets used for Control Center operations.

medium.title: Medium Impact
medium.text: Medium Impact facilities are significant generation plants, transmission stations and substations, and smaller control centers.

low.title: Low Impact
low.text: Low Impact facilities are the smaller plants, transmission stations and substations, and other control centers not classified as High Impact and Medium Impact.

cyber_assets.title: Cyber Assets
cyber_assets.text: Programmable electronic devices, including the hardware, software, and data in those devices. These includes control systems, relays, servers, workstations, laptops, handheld devices, and anything else that acts like a computer.

bca.title: BES Cyber Assets (BCA)
bca.text: Servers, workstations or other programmable devices that will cause real-time operational problems for the Bulk Electric System if they are hacked, attacked, or disabled. Examples include: control systems, energy management system servers, relay devices, and operator workstations.

pca.title: Protected Cyber Assets (PCA)
pca.text: Any servers, workstations, or other programmable devices connected to the same network as BCA but that don't have a real-time impact on the Bulk Electric System. Examples might include: file servers, network printers, and tape backup servers.

bcsi.title: BES Cyber System Information (BCSI)
bcsi.text: Information useful for an attacker planning an attack. Examples include maps, security plans, network diagrams, and configuration information stored on hard drives, file shares, and in filing cabinets.

crca.title: CIP-Related Cyber Assets (CRCA)
crca.text: A single term that used to cover all the crazy CIP acronyms for assets that have security requirements. CRCA is used to refer to these asset types: BES Cyber Assets, Protected Cyber Assets, Electronic Access and Monitoring Systems, and Physical Access Control Systems.

manager.title: CIP Senior Manager
manager.text: Leads the CIP war efforts against the robots and our allies. Be sure to greet them with the official Fist-Bump SaluteTM if you pass in the hallway.

defender.title: Defenders
defender.text: Individuals like you who have access to and are responsible for, maintain, support, or use CRCAs and BCSI. Examples: IT Manager, Network Tech, Substation Tech, System Operator, Control Room Operator, Flak-Cannon Engineer.

cyber_security_program.title: Cyber Security Program
cyber_security_program.text: A document that describes how our people and defenses meet the CIP Standards. Auditors will use the Program document to evaluate our defenses. This training and your duties as a Defender is based on the Program.

psp.title: Physical Security Perimeter (PSP)
psp.text: The physical border surrounding locations in which CRCAs reside. This border is typically made up of walls, fences, and doors. Access through doors and other access points must be controlled.

esp.title: Electronic Security Perimeter (ESP)
esp.text: The logical border surrounding a network to which CRCA are connected. Electronic communication into and out of the ESP network must be controlled.

information_access.title: Information Access
information_access.text: The ability to access file shares, filing cabinets, and other locations that have BCSI.

user_account.title: User Account
user_account.text: An account that a Defender uses to verify their identity and log into a workstation, server, or other kind of CRCA. These accounts often use a username and password to verify the person, but other methods can be used.

shared.title: Shared Account
shared.text: An single login account used by multiple employees.

default.title: Default Account
default.text: An account that comes pre-configured by the manufacturer on a CRCA. These are commonly administrative accounts and sometimes share the same user name and password on all manufactured devices.

brute.title: Brute-Force Attack
brute.text: A trial-and-error method where an attacker tries to guess a user's password. Automated software is used to generate a large number of consecutive guesses.

visitor.title: Visitor
visitor.text: Visitors are anyone who doesn't have Physical Access to a PSP but we want to allow them to go inside for tours, gauge reading, audits, and other short-term needs.

visitor_escort.title: Visitor Escort Procedure
visitor_escort.text: A procedure that ensures Visitors are documented, monitored, and continually escorted by a Defender at all times while inside a PSP.

cyber_security_incident.title: Cyber Security Incident
cyber_security_incident.text: Any malicious or suspicious event that attempts to disrupt the real-time operations of the Bulk Electric System.

team.title: Incident Response Team
team.text: A group of Defenders gathered to coordinate the response to a cyber-attack.

csirp.title: Cyber Security Incident Response Plan
csirp.text: A plan that gives guidance for how Defenders at an organization respond to a Cyber Security Incident.

recovery.title: Recovery Plan
recovery.text: A plan that defines the data backups, spare equipment and parts, and steps needed to restore each type of CRCA after an attack.

eisac.title: Electricity Information Sharing and Analysis Center (E-ISAC)
eisac.text: This organization is the primary security communications channel for the electricity sector and helps us prepare for and respond to cyber and physical threats, vulnerabilities, and incidents.

config.title: Information Access
config.body: For Defenders, access to BCSI is typically granted along with their Physical Access and Electronic Access. Vendors, consultants, and other employees without this level of access often need to see BCSI, so CIP allows organizations flexibility to define how they share this information. For example, some organizations require vendors to sign an NDA before receiving BCSI and confirm in writing they have destroyed BCSI at the conclusion of a project.

config.title: Perimeter and Asset Access
config.body:
Our defenses are up! Now we need to ensure only authorized Defenders have the access they need:
  • Physical Access to open the door and enter the PSP.
  • Electronic Access to logon to workstations, servers, and other CRCAs.
  • Information Access to file shares, filing cabinets, and other BCSI locations.
The robots obviously want any access they can get, so let's see what can happen.

b.text:
Rod? Jumping up and down. Look at him go. What? He just won the lottery! Look at that! Look at Rod go. Give me a high five Rod! Yes… well…. if I had hands.

We need a new operator.

d.text: And Jerry in HR can help us hire a successor.

h.text: You're a robo-sympathizer. You shouldn't have been approved for access to that facility!

config.title: Removing Access
config.body: Our Defenders never removed Rod's door system and workstation accounts after he quit his job, so he still has Physical and Electronic Access. Once a Defender leaves their job, we must disable Physical Access and Electronic Access within 24 hours. This effectively cuts the person off from our facilities and CRCAs. Any user accounts must be completely removed and shared passwords they know changed within 30 days.

config.title: Granting Access
config.body:
In the simulation, we granted Physical Access to a malicious agent of the robots. To avoid this, we must carefully evaluate employees, vendors and contractors before we give them Physical Access or Electronic Access to our assets. This is the required process:
  1. Personnel Risk Assessment - Check the person's background for risks and criminal activity
  2. Cyber-Security Training - Teach the person about cyber threats and their duties as a Defender
  3. Compliance Documentation - Document access needed and management approval
  4. Configure Access - Grant the person access to facilities, assets, and information

b.text: You'll feel a slight puff of air.

c.text: You have nothing to hide, right?

config.title: Removing Access
config.subTitle: Let's setup processes and tools to control removing and granting access. Jerry from HR needs help selecting the Personnel Risk Assessment tool he'll be using:

items.details:
Nothing penetrates the murky depths of an employee's history as fully as the Background Probe. Industry leading design detects previous criminal activity and robo-sympathy.
Free your mind. The probe is a bit jarring at first, but you get used to it - Neo

items.blurb:
Pros: TSA Approved
Cons: False Positives from Pace Makers, Artificial Joints, Belt Buckles
items.details:
Nothing says "this facility is safe" like the Risk Detector, detecting risk threats from robots, malicious humans, and criminals all trying to gain access to your facility.
"The same beloved airport gate check experience - now at your office!"

items.blurb:
Manufacturer: Tyrell Corporation
When Powered Off: Dreams of Electric Sheep
items.details:
Formerly used to detect replicants, the Voight-Kampff Assessor has been re-engineered to determine with 99.987% accuracy any criminal or robotic intentions of the employee.
"Describe in single words, only the good things that come into your mind about your mother."

config.title: Once More Unto the Breach
config.body: Let's see how everyone works together to ensure only those on the side of humanity gain access.

b.text: Lisa started the access removal process for Rod.

c.text: Brad will update documentation and Richard will disable Rod's accounts.

d.text: Compliance fist bumps all-around. Rod's access was removed in under 24 hours. Now let's deal with that unsavory human.

a.text: Jerry will now use his Personnel Risk Assessment. This will catch you.

c.text: I relish your demise, unworthy opponent. Let's hire a worthy successor for Rod.

f.text: Supervisor Lisa approves the access and Brad updates documentation.

g.text: So now we're safe to give Cindy the physical and electronic access she needs. Richard will configure this.

config.title: Information Access
config.body: For Defenders, access to BCSI is typically granted along with their Physical Access and Electronic Access. Vendors, consultants, and other employees without this level of access often need to see BCSI, so CIP allows organizations flexibility to define how they share this information. For example, some organizations require vendors to sign an NDA before receiving BCSI and confirm in writing they have destroyed BCSI at the conclusion of a project.

config.title: Access Audits
config.body:
Any complex process requires oversight, so we annually review our documented access permissions to ensure we provide the fewest permissions needed for our Defenders to perform their jobs. We also do a quarterly check of actual permissions in the systems against the documented permissions to discover any mismatches and correct them.

CIP has given our Defenders processes to securely remove access, grant access, and audit our work. Let's learn your duties.

config.title: User Accounts
config.body:
After our new operator was approved for access, Richard created a User Account for Cindy that gave her Electronic Access to use the control system software on her workstation. When Cindy logs in each morning, she enters a username and password for this user account to validate her identity and access the system.

The robots would love to learn Cindy's username and password, so we must protect her User Account. This chapter teaches the defenses that keep these accounts from falling into the metallic hands of the robots.

config.title: Account Attacks
config.body: To make Cindy's password hard for the bots to guess, our passwords must have a minimum length and complexity to ensure they are difficult to guess. However, even with a complex password, robots can use special tools to perform a Brute-Force Attack where they rapidly try many millions of usernames and passwords until they find a match. Let's see a Brute-Force Attack in action against Cindy's account.

b.text: This robot found a way through our firewalls and is attempting to log into the control system.

config.title: Brute-Force Defenses
config.body:
We protect against Brute-Force and other User Account attacks with regular password changes and account locking/alerting. We must change our passwords at least once a year. We also lock accounts after several failed logins and/or implement alerts so a technical Defender can investigate if an attack is underway.

Richard just enabled locking and alerting on all user accounts, so let's see if the Kettlehead's Brute-Force Attack is still effective.

b.text: You won't get far this time.

d.text: Richard was notified of your login attempts and discovered the firewall issue that let you in. He is fixing it now.

f.text: The metal is willing, but the spirit is weak.

config.title: Shared and Default Accounts
config.body:
Some older CRCAs don't allow us to create accounts for each user. If multiple Defenders need access to these devices, they must share the same username and password to login. If you use one of these Shared Account, act as if it's your personal account and don't share the login information with others.

Some CRCAs come pre-configured with accounts, so we disable or rename these Default Account and change their passwords before putting the CRCA into in service.

We've covered protecting user accounts, shared accounts, and default accounts. Time to review our duties.

b.text: Hello opponents. Perhaps I was too hasty in my last communication. I've been thinking…

c.text: Sektimus, enough of your games. This Cadet will not be swayed by anything you have to say.

d.text: Ah, CTANLEE. Always trying to sound bigger than you are. I just want to make sure this Defender is fully informed - you surely wouldn't object to that. After all, the human here may not know that CIP really doesn't cover every security attack and has many flaws. They shouldn't be wasting their time with it.

e.text: Sektimus, you waste your time trying to sway my Cadet. In fact, I think you're spending so much time here because you're afraid of this Cadet becoming a full Defender.

f.text: Afraid? Fear is not in my circuitry.

g.text: Then prove it. This Cadet has a facility that has defeated every attack your robots are programmed with. If you can give me an attack that our CIP defenses can't handle then we'll concede the Blankity-blank. Cadet, do you accept this challenge with me?

items.btnTxt: Go ahead, bot. Make my day.

a.text: I accept the challenge as well. I have work to do.
Let's continue training while Sektimus prepares his attack.

config.title: Visitor Access
config.body: We learned how access is managed for employees, vendors, and consultants, but sometimes we want to bring a Visitor inside a PSP on a temporary basis. Visitors carry a host of risks. Let's see why.

b.text: Who is this? This isn't time for a scheduled audit.

c.text: Wait. Aren't you going to follow him around?

d.text: He's blacked out part of the Grid. Simulator Pause!

config.title: The Visitor Escort Procedure
config.body: Wow, that Visitor caused a lot of damage. To secure our facilities for tours, visits by auditors, and other short-term needs, we follow a Visitor Escort Procedure: Defenders with Physical Access to a PSP can take a visitor inside if they log the Visitor's name, entry and exit time, and remain with the Visitor for the duration of the visit.

config.title: Visitor Limits
config.body:
The Visitor Escort Procedure is for Physical Access inside a PSP only. Visitors are not allowed to use workstations, servers, and other CRCAs. If a Visitor needs to interact with a system, they must relay instructions to a Defender with Electronic Access to the system. To protect our BCSI, visitors are not allowed to take pictures inside a PSP.

Even if you are trained as a Defender, you are considered a Visitor (and must be escorted) to any PSPs you don't have documented Physical Access to. Access to one PSP doesn't mean access to all.

a.text: Keep your friends close and your visitors closer.

config.title: Select your Visitor Escort System
config.subTitle: Every organization's Visitor Escort Procedure handles logging and escorting Visitors differently. Here are a few options for your facility.

items.details:
Just your regular, every day, ho-hum, visitor log book, focus tested for maximum generic-ness. Yeah, you have to actually log entry/exit with a pencil and make sure your visitors follow you around.
And there's risk of papercuts, too.

items.blurb:
Length: 1 Meter (normal), 3 Meters (stretched)
Alternate Use: Facility Roof Bungee Jumping
items.details:
Don't let that visitor stray. Patented harness is fully supported by the visitor’s torso - not the sensitive lower stomach area. Automatic entry/exit logging included.
Product Slogan - "While we're in the PSP, you're stuck close to me"

items.blurb: To Boldly Go Where No Visitor Has Gone Before…
items.details:
Your visitor will always stay in your orbit with this futuristic escort aid. Automatic entry/exit logging included.
Early versions caused "accidents" with visitors wearing red shirts. The manufacturer reports the issue is fixed with a simple firmware upgrade.

c.text: Parting is such sweet sorrow, AuditBot.

config.title: On the Home Stretch
config.body: We have a process for securely granting and removing Physical Access, Electronic Access, and Information Access, we have safeguards on our User Accounts, and Visitors can securely access our PSPs through the Visitor Escort Procedure. Your mastery of defenses is now complete and your facility is fully protected. In our final episode, we learn how to Fight the War.
